clue: Rescue smashed safe (6)
explanation: When RESCUE is “smashed,” or anagrammed, you get SECURE (“safe”).

clue: Disappear like a vehicle? (6)
explanation: VANISH (“disappear”) is also VAN-ISH (“like a vehicle?”). The question mark indicates that the wordplay is not quite literal.

clue: Dispatch satisfactory giggles (9)
explanation: S (“satisfactory”) plus LAUGHTER (“giggles”) gives you SLAUGHTER (“dispatch”).

clue: Worn tech ruined show (3,5)
explanation: “Ruin,” or anagram, WORN TECH to get THE CROWN, a “show.”

clue: William discussed impressions of sea creatures (6,2,5)
explanation: With thanks to those who found the pun first, PRINCE OF WALES (“William”) is a homophone (“discussed”) of PRINTS OF WHALES (“impressions of sea creatures”).

clue: Large-scale alteration of Exit Seven (9)
explanation: Make an “alteration,” or anagram, of EXIT SEVEN to get EXTENSIVE (“large-scale”).

clue: First time without you generates obligation (4)
explanation: Hoping this isn’t the last . DEBT is the “obligation” that’s “generated” when you drop the letter U (“without you”) from DEBUT (“first time”).

clue: Parasite’s marking (4)
explanation: TICK is both a type of “parasite” and a “marking” (as in “tick all the boxes”).

clue: Malcolm and Theodore meet up for a drink (6)
explanation: When MAL (“Malcolm”) and TED (“Theodore”) “meet up,” you get MALTED, a “drink.”

clue: Candidate who’s expected to win confounded fair vote (8)
explanation: “Confound,” or anagram, FAIR VOTE to get FAVORITE (“candidate who’s expected to win”).

clue: Fly eating wasp’s second skin (4)
explanation: FLY (given directly in the clue) “eats” the letter A (“wasp’s second,” or the second letter of WASP) to make FLAY (“skin” in its verb sense).

clue: French region accepts identification for American city (10)
explanation: When PROVENCE, a “French region,” “accepts,” or contains, the letters ID (“identification”), you get the “American city” of PROVIDENCE.

clue: Quick swim with hot, revealing swimwear—it’s seen in strait (9)
explanation: DIPHTHONG is something “seen in strait,” which you get from DIP (“quick swim”) plus H (“hot”) plus THONG (“revealing swimwear”).

clue: Be left with popular pair of pronouns (7)
explanation: We made it to  and Twitter is not dead (yet)! INHERIT (“be left with”) is IN (“popular”) plus HER and IT, a “pair of pronouns.”

clue: Cocktail of soda and rum makes tasty Cuban treat (7)
explanation: Make a “cocktail,” or anagram, of the words SODA and RUM to get MADUROS, a “tasty Cuban treat.”

clue: Shortstop seizes opening in baseball, etc. (6)
explanation: The abbreviation SS (“shortstop”) “seizes,” or contains, the word PORT (“opening”) to create SPORTS (“baseball, etc.”).

clue: Pegs rotate front to back (4)
explanation: Take SPIN (“rotate”) and move the first letter to the end (“front to back”) to get PINS (“pegs”).

clue: Measure of protection for Spanish furbaby (7)
explanation: The definition is the hard part in this one: PARAPET is the “measure of protection” you get from PARA (“for Spanish,” or a way to say “for” in Spanish) and PET (“furbaby”).

clue: Too many to number, not including Lebanon’s First Lady (8)
explanation: COUNTLESS (“too many to number”) drops (“not including”) the letter L (“Lebanon’s First,” or the first letter of LEBANON) to get COUNTESS, a “lady.”

clue: Time request for job (4)
explanation: T (“time”) plus ASK (“request”) makes TASK (“job”). Simple!

clue: Blonde lady botched legal raid (9)
explanation: We’ve made it to another ! In this anagram, LEGAL RAID is “botched” to become GALADRIEL, a “blonde lady.”

clue: British guy and Spanish guy in place of worship (6)
explanation: Put CHAP (“British guy”) and ÉL (“Spanish guy,” as in the Spanish word for “he,” ignoring the accent mark) together to get CHAPEL, a “place of worship.”

clue: Notice entity in a rage (8)
explanation: SEETHING (“in a rage”) is SEE (“notice”) plus THING (“entity”).

clue: Peers spoil rewritten graphic novel (10)
explanation: PEERS SPOIL is “rewritten,” or anagrammed, to make the “graphic novel” PERSEPOLIS.

clue: For an audience, seasonal seasoning is a neat trick (10)
explanation: SOMERSAULT (“a neat trick”) is a homophone (“for an audience”) of SUMMER SALT (“seasonal seasoning”).

clue: Beginnings of bright, unusually fine future for enthusiast (4)
explanation: In this acrostic clue, take the first letters, or “beginnings of,” the next four words in the clue to get BUFF, an “enthusiast.”

clue: Herb Dash wears prayer necklace (8)
explanation: When EM, a type of “dash” (ignore the deceptive capitalization), “wears,” or is inserted into, ROSARY (“prayer necklace”), you get the “herb” ROSEMARY.

clue: Monitor Puerto Rico Doctors Without Borders (7)
explanation:
Phew, it’s !

Put PR (“Puerto Rico”) with OCTOR (“Doctors Without Borders,” or the word DOCTORS missing its “border” letters) to get PROCTOR (“monitor”).

clue: Standard article, not French temple (9)
explanation: PAR (“standard”) plus THE (the definite “article”) plus NON (“not French,” or “not” in French) gives you the “temple” PARTHENON.

clue: Lady’s diminutive French pastry? (7)
explanation: GAL-ETTE could be a “lady’s diminutive,” and GALETTE is a “French pastry.” The question mark indicates the non-literal nature of the wordplay.

clue: Powerful #1 Hill worker grabs you (8)
explanation: PUISSANT (“powerful”) is what you get when PISS (#1) plus ANT (“Hill worker,” as in a working insect that lives in a hill) “grabs” the letter U (“you”).

clue: Feature of carpet family is a bit of table linen (6)
explanation: NAP (“feature of carpet”) plus KIN (“family”) gives you NAPKIN “a bit of table linen”).

clue: Mourns epic, ruined stage part (10)
explanation: MOURNS EPIC is “ruined,” or anagrammed, to get PROSCENIUM, a “stage part.”

clue: Stag, say, eats head of petunia and tree (5)
explanation: MALE (“stag, say”) “eats” the letter P (the first letter, or “head,”) of PETUNIA) to make MAPLE, a “tree.”

clue: Make things better without the last comedy (6)
explanation: It’s  again! IMPROVE (“make things better”) “without the last” letter gives you the answer, IMPROV (“comedy”).

clue: Greek island sausages (7)
explanation: In this double definition, SALAMIS is both a “Greek island” and “sausages.”

clue: Dueled agitated fool (6)
explanation: “Agitate,” or anagram, the word DUELED to get DELUDE (“fool” in its verb sense).

clue: Assistant of knight and yours truly (4)
explanation: SIRI is the “assistant” you get from SIR (“knight”) plus I (“yours truly”).

clue: Cool, average guys on Second and Third (5)
explanation: “Cool” is a fall-appropriate definition of CRISP, which you get from C (“average,” as in the letter grade) plus RISP (the baseball abbreviation for “runners in scoring position,” or “guys on second and third”). Ignore the deceptive capital letters!

clue: A thousand got together, surrounding our old magazine (7)
explanation: G = “a thousand” and MET = “got together.” When they “surround” OUR (given directly in the clue), you get the “old magazine” GOURMET.

clue: Philadelphia school with impressive and popular advocate for neurodiverse thinkers (6,7)
explanation: The “advocate for neurodiverse thinkers” is TEMPLE GRANDIN. TEMPLE is a “Philadelphia school”; GRAND is “impressive”; IN is “popular.”

clue: Sounds like horses' team that's very exciting rn (8)
explanation: It’s the PHILLIES (“team that’s very exciting rn”), of course! They “sound like” FILLIES, or “horses.”

clue: Quiet-quitting clergyperson causes crime (5)
explanation: We made it to ! ARSON is the “crime” “caused” when P (“quiet,” as in the musical marking) “quits,” or leaves, PARSON (“clergyperson”).

clue: Child and adult actress (6)
explanation: “Actress” Nicole KIDMAN’s name is made by adding KID (“child”) and MAN (“adult”).

clue: Imagine, in a whirlwind, losing one puzzle (6)
explanation: Anagram (“in a whirlwind”) IMAGINE and take away one of the Is (“losing one,” as in Roman numeral I) to get ENIGMA (“puzzle”).

clue: Drink made entirely from components of spiral (12)
explanation: In this letter bank, SPIRAL contains all of the unique letters in (“made entirely from components of”) SARSAPARILLA (“drink”).

clue: Musical assistant took a trip on ecstasy, it’s said (6)
explanation: Tough one! ROADIE (“musical assistant”) is a homophone (“it’s said”) of RODE E (“took a trip on” = ROAD; “ecstasy” = E).

clue: Gamer got bad loan (8)
explanation: Anagram (“bad”) GAMER GOT to get MORTGAGE (“loan”).

clue: Reverend’s method Newman used to make content restriction (7)
explanation: Spoonerize (“Reverend’s”) WAY PAUL (“method” and “Newman” respectively) to get PAYWALL, a “content restriction.”

clue: Spanish-English fireplaces (6)
explanation: has arrived! INGLÉS means “English” in Spanish (“Spanish-English”); without the accent mark, INGLES is an old-timey word meaning “fireplaces.”

clue: Song having less feeling (6)
explanation: In this double definition, NUMBER is both a “song” and a word meaning “having less feeling” (i.e., more numb).

clue: Composer lurks in Carousel Gardens (5)
explanation: Edward ELGAR is the “composer” who’s “lurking in” the phrase “carousEL GARdens.” (Carousel Gardens is an amusement park in New Orleans, btw.)

clue: Melanie, nearly failing in card game action (4)
explanation: MELD (“card game action”) is MEL (“Melanie”) plus D (“nearly failing,” as in the grade).

clue: Margaret temporarily provided Shabbat meal (7)
explanation: CHO (“Margaret,” i.e., comic Margaret CHO) plus LENT (“temporarily provided”) gives you CHOLENT, a “Shabbat meal.”

clue: Expert loses head for flower (5)
explanation: “Lose the head,” or remove the first letter from, MASTER (“expert”) to get ASTER, a “flower.”

clue: Washington deserts facilities, leaving behind fungus (6)
explanation: When WA (“Washington”) “deserts” the word WASHROOM (“facilities”), SHROOM is the “fungus” that’s “left behind.”

clue: Bird on fire beside ocean’s head (8)
explanation: It’s ! FLAMINGO (“bird”) is FLAMING (“on fire”) plus O (“ocean’s head,” or the first letter of OCEAN).

clue: You quitting a company? That’s a cliche (5)
explanation: When the letter U (“you”) “quits,” or leaves, TROUPE (“a company”), you get TROPE (“That’s a cliche”).

clue: Hi, open broken device (6)
explanation: IPHONE is the “device” you get from “breaking,” or anagramming, HI OPEN.

clue: That man, at that time, captured one unbeliever (7)
explanation: HE THEN (“that man” and “at that time” respectively) “captures” the letter A (“one,” in the indefinite article sense) to make HEATHEN (“unbeliever”).

clue: Pitches a bizarre imitation (8)
explanation: A PASTICHE is an “imitation” that comes from anagramming (“bizarre”) PITCHES A.

clue: Type of protest takes on Yemen’s first form of government (7)
explanation: Enumeration should’ve been (8) for MONARCHY, a “form of government” you get when MARCH (“type of protest”) “takes,” or contains, the word ON, with Y (“Yemen’s first”) at the end.

clue: Observing nothing, having no heart (6)
explanation: NOTING (“observing”) is NOTHING (given in the clue) without its middle letter (“having no heart”).

clue: Like a quiet period composer? (5)
explanation: Time for some explanations! French “composer” (Jean-Baptiste) LULLY’s name could be said to be “like a quiet period” (LULL-Y). The question mark indicates the non-literal nature of the wordplay.

clue: Sing and laugh, make a beer (6)
explanation: SING (given in the clue) and HA (“laugh”) “make a beer”: SINGHA.

clue: Amsterdam Avenue constituents include expert (5)
explanation: Another hidden-word clue: the answer, MAVEN, is in the middle of (“constituents include”) the phrase “AmsterdaM AVENue.”

clue: Shall lose the opening entrance (4)
explanation: “Lose the opening,” or remove the first letter, of the word SHALL (given directly in the clue) to get HALL (“entrance”).

clue: Doggo eats in cradle (8)
explanation: When BASSET, a type of “doggo,” “eats” the word IN (given directly in the clue, so it’s not an extraneous connector word), you get BASSINET, a “cradle.”

clue: Machiavellian villain clutches heavy equipment (5)
explanation: In this hidden-word clue, the phrase “machiavelliAN VILlain” “clutches” the answer, ANVIL (“heavy equipment”).

clue: Messy place with the French fashions (6)
explanation: STYLES (“fashions”) is STY (“messy place”) plus LES (“the French,” or a way to say “the” in French).

clue: Movie general starts to lead everyone in alliance (4)
explanation: What a week! It’s . In this acrostic clue, “movie general” LEIA is formed from the “starts to,” or first letters of, the last four words in the clue.

clue: Sounds like UK (English) composer (7)
explanation: (Benjamin) BRITTEN is the “English composer” whose name is a homophone (“sounds like”) of BRITAIN (“UK”).

clue: Nonconformists insult big men in speech (10)
explanation: DISSENTERS (“nonconformists”) is a homophone (“in speech”) of DIS CENTERS (“insult big men,” in the NBA sense of “big men”).

clue: Symphony encompasses the first Madonna album (7)
explanation: Tough one! EROICA, a “symphony,” “encompasses” the letter T (“the first,” or the first letter of “the”) to give you EROTICA, a “Madonna album.”

clue: Local testosterone injected into innocent (6)
explanation: “Inject” the letter T (“testosterone”) into NAIVE (“innocent”) to get NATIVE (“local”).

clue: Company spread something you see at Comic-Con (7)
explanation: COSPLAY (“something you see at Comic-Con”) is CO (an abbreviation for “company”) plus SPLAY (“spread”).

clue: That pop music legend, Maggie from the UK (8)
explanation: THAT (given in the clue) plus CHER (“pop music legend”) makes THATCHER (“Maggie from the UK”).

clue: German mom’s grumble (6)
explanation: Thank goodness it’s ! In this double definition, MUTTER is the German word for “mother” (“German mom”) as well as a synonym for “grumble.”

clue: Keep at it, fool (4)
explanation: In this double definition, GO ON (“keep at it”) makes GOON (“fool”).

clue: Reign of gruesome alien (7)
explanation: Anagram (“gruesome”) REIGN OF to get FOREIGN (“alien”).

clue: Broadcast legends in possession of fancy residence (6)
explanation: Surprise! “Broadcast” doesn’t indicate a homophone here: it’s part of a hidden-word phrase. “broadCAST LEgends” is “in possession of” the word CASTLE, a “fancy residence.”

clue: Reinforcement of kidnapper’s demand coming after time (7)
explanation: TRANSOM is the “reinforcement” you get from RANSOM (“kidnapper’s demand”) “coming after” the letter T (an abbreviation for “time”).

clue: Bathes in stirred alcoholic drink (8)
explanation: “Stir,” or anagram, BATHES IN, to get ABSINTHE, an “alcoholic drink.”

clue: Gym class with purple garment style (6)
explanation: Fashion! PEPLUM is the “garment style” you get from PE (“gym class”) plus PLUM (“purple”).

clue: Cart contains all the makings of waterfall (8)
explanation: We made it! It’s ! In this letter bank clue, CART “contains all the makings of,” or has all the letters used in, CATARACT (“waterfall”).

clue: Resist rock band (7,6)
explanation: In this unusual reverse anagram, TWISTED SISTER is the “rock band.” The word RESIST in the clue is an anagram of SISTER, so it’s a “twisted SISTER.”

clue: Agitate bitter oil to find fossil (9)
explanation: “Agitate,” or anagram, BITTER OIL to find TRILOBITE, a “fossil.”

clue: Cuddly pet’s pot (5)
explanation: In this double definition, KITTY is both a “cuddly pet” and the “pot” in a poker game.

clue: Double barrier: a city in Washington (5,5)
explanation: WALL (“barrier”) plus A (given in the clue) is WALLA. “Double” that to get WALLA WALLA (“city in Washington”).

clue: Math practitioner’s season? (6)
explanation: SUMMER is both a “math practitioner” (in the sense of someone who’s doing sums) and a “season.” The question mark indicates the non-literal nature of one of the definitions.

clue: Phosphorus with every fruit (5)
explanation: Easier one: P (the elemental symbol of “phosphorus”) “with” EACH (“every”) makes PEACH, a “fruit.”

clue: Union member trialist gathers in the morning (8)
explanation: Welcome to ! TEAMSTER (“union member”) is TESTER (“trialist”) “gathering” AM, or “in the morning.”

clue: Note belonging to me spells disaster (6)
explanation: FA (a musical “note”) plus MINE (“belonging to me”) “spells” FAMINE, a “disaster.”

clue: Relief occurs in confusion (6)
explanation: Anagram (“in confusion”) OCCURS to get SUCCOR (“relief”).

clue: Sing the French song (6)
explanation: SINGLE is the “song” you get from SING (given in the clue) plus LE (“the French,” or “the” in French).

clue: Variety is essential to Katy Perry (4)
explanation: TYPE is the “variety” “essential to,” or hidden in, “kaTY PErry.”

clue: Feel sorry about wading bird subreddit? (6)
explanation: Subreddits are of the form “r/name,” so R/EGRET (“wading bird subreddit?”) is REGRET (“feel sorry about”). The question mark indicates the not-quite-literal wordplay.

clue: Stirred rum becomes unmanageable (10)
explanation: “Stir,” or anagram, RUM BECOMES to get CUMBERSOME (“unmanageable”).

clue: Clog giant container of extension (6)
explanation: has arrived! In this hidden-word clue, LOGGIA is the (architectural) “extension”) “contained” in “cLOG GIAnt.”

clue: Ask for identification from popular cruciverbalist (6)
explanation: CARD (“ask for identification from”) plus IN (“popular”) produces “cruciverbalist” (Nate) CARDIN. Just can’t stop cluing @naytnaytnayt!

clue: Alien guy from Chicago and so on (2,6)
explanation: ET CETERA (“and so on”) is ET (“alien”) plus (Peter) CETERA, a “guy from Chicago” (the band).

clue: French insolence, I see (6)
explanation: GALLIC (“French”) comes from GALL (“insolence”) plus I C (“I see”—think text message abbreviations).

clue: Transience changed fruits (10)
explanation: Anagram (“changed”) TRANSIENCE to get NECTARINES (“fruits”).

clue: Booze recipe from the Reverend’s party factory (4,4)
explanation: I think the definition is the hard part here: MASH BILL is a “booze recipe” (it’s the ratio of grain types that go into a beer or whiskey), and it comes from spoonerizing (“the Reverend’s) BASH MILL (“party factory”).

clue: To a Spaniard, my anger is an illusion (6)
explanation: MIRAGE is “an illusion” made from MI (“to a Spaniard, my,” or “my” in Spanish) plus RAGE (“anger”).

clue: Prussian noble’s shitty car (6)
explanation: This is a double definition: JUNKER is both a “Prussian noble” and a “shitty car.”

clue: Four entering sexual public revelry (8)
explanation: Phew! It’s ! Some tough clues this week. In this one, IV (“four” in Roman numerals) “enters” CARNAL (“sexual”) to produce CARNIVAL (“public revelry”).

clue: Easy job is awfully nice, sure (8)
explanation: Anagram (“awfully”) NICE SURE to get SINECURE (“easy job”).

clue: Use a spade on small, humble dwelling (6)
explanation: Oops, guess I used “small” the same way twice in one week: S (“small”) plus HOVEL (“humble dwelling”) makes SHOVEL (“use a spade on”).

clue: Debussy’s “Scratched” on the radio (6)
explanation: CLAUDE (“Debussy”) is a homophone (“on the radio”) of CLAWED (“Scratched”). The placement of “on the radio” indicates which word is the def and which is the homophone.

clue: Centaur, or chimerical teller of tales (9)
explanation: Anagram (“chimerical”) CENTAUR OR to get RACONTEUR, a “teller of tales.”

clue: Patricia and Ronald meet up for tequila (6)
explanation: Phew, this one was easier! PAT plus RON (“Patricia and Ronald”) equals PATRON, a brand of “tequila.”

clue: With that guy’s essential brown sauce? (7)
explanation: The question mark indicates a non-literal definition (“brown sauce?”) for WHISKEY, which is W (“with”) plus HIS (“that guy’s”) plus KEY (“essential”).

clue: A little bit—small—making a difference (10)
explanation: It’s ! This is just a charade: S (“small”) plus MATTERING (“making a difference”) makes SMATTERING (“a little bit”).

clue: Half of very nice film festival location (6)
explanation: VENICE is the “film festival location” you get from VE (“half of very,” or the first half of VERY) plus NICE (given directly in the clue).

clue: Newsworthy winner gave daring arrangement (10)
explanation: Anagram (“arrangement”) GAVE DARING to get VINGEGAARD, a “newsworthy winner” (of the Tour de France, that is).

clue: Lacking in money, getting nothing, becoming a great constructor (6)
explanation: BROOKE @xandraladee is the “great constructor” you get from BROKE (“lacking money”) “receiving” the letter O (“nothing,” in which O is used to represent zero).

clue: Switch first and third of Spanish artist’s exercise (4)
explanation: Take GOYA (“Spanish artist”) and “switch [the] first and third [letters]” to get YOGA (“exercise”).

clue: That lady will fire heavy projectiles (5)
explanation: “That lady will” is SHE’LL, which without the apostrophe is SHELL (“fire heavy projectiles”).

clue: Repartee is popular amid terrible time (8)
explanation: This time “terrible” isn’t an anagram indicator: it’s just defining BAD. A “terrible time” is a BAD AGE; add IN (“popular”) in the middle to get BADINAGE (“repartee”).

clue: Regularly inspire something to listen to (3)
explanation: Take every other letter (2, 4, and 6; “regularly”) of INSPIRE to get NPR (“something to listen to”).

clue: Stunning songbird eats tulip top (9)
explanation: It’s finally ! In this clue, STARLING (“songbird”) “eats” the letter T (“tulip top,” or the first letter of TULIP) to make STARTLING (“stunning”).

clue: Left in place: Monument for ancient philosopher (8)
explanation: Add L (“left”) “in” PUT (“place”) to get PLUT; then add ARCH (“monument”) at the end to get PLUTARCH (“ancient philosopher”).

clue: Weapons of sister with sneakers (9)
explanation: NUNCHUCKS (“weapons”) comes from NUN (“sister”) plus CHUCKS (“sneakers,” i.e., Chuck Taylors).

clue: Condom head found in shoe causes quite a stir (7)
explanation: Put C (“condom head,” or the first letter of CONDOM) into (“found in”) SANDAL (“shoe”) to get SCANDAL (“quite a stir”).

clue: Come to a resolution about Delaware murder? (6)
explanation: DE (“Delaware”) plus the suffix -CIDE (“murder”) gives you DECIDE (“come to a resolution about”). The question mark indicates the non-literal wordplay.

clue: Doggo, someday in disarray (7)
explanation: Anagram (“in disarray”) SOMEDAY to get SAMOYED, a kind of “doggo.”

clue: The ones here with American (Greek) hero (7)
explanation: THESEUS (“Greek hero,” ignoring punctuation) is THESE (“the ones here”) plus US (“American”).

clue: Work with needles, keeping time for a little bit of music (8)
explanation: The specialized knowledge here is that another name for a quarter note is a CROTCHET (“a little bit of music”), which you get from CROCHET (“work with needles”) “keeping” the letter T (“time”).

clue: Open actual rotten melon (10)
explanation: Anagram (“rotten”) OPEN ACTUAL to get CANTALOUPE (“melon”).

clue: Message hidden in lazy rock variety (11)
explanation: Put IM (“message”) in SEDENTARY (“lazy”) to get SEDIMENTARY (“rock variety”).

clue: Fish with hiding place where plants grow (6)
explanation: GARDEN (“where plants grow”) is GAR (a type of “fish”) plus DEN (“hiding place”).

clue: Crete’s ruin is not to be spoken of (6)
explanation: “Ruin,” or anagram, CRETES to get “secret” (“not to be spoken of”).

clue: Crews’ fabric (5)
explanation: TERRY is both the first name of TV personality “Crews,” and also a “fabric.”

clue: Anger, confusion about one city in Canada (6)
explanation: Anagram (“confusion”) ANGER into REGNA, then put it “about” (aboot?) the letter I (“one” in Roman numerals) to get REGINA (“city in Canada”).

clue: Tree and sheep in retreat (6)
explanation: Whew! It’s ! An ASH is a tree and a RAM is a sheep; put them together to get ASHRAM, a “retreat.”

clue: Small jerk’s impertinence (4)
explanation: SASS (“impertinence”) is S (an abbreviation for “small”) plus ASS (“jerk”).

clue: Some paper from edited theses (6)
explanation: When the word THESES is “edited,” or anagrammed, you get SHEETS (“some paper”).

clue: The reverend said sexual content publicity makes a lively dance (8)
explanation: Any time you see “the reverend,” a spoonerism is involved: spoonerize PORN HYPE (“sexual content publicity”) to get HORNPIPE, a “lively dance.”

clue: Composer is, to a great extent, America (5)
explanation: SOUSA (“composer”) is SO (“to a great extent”) plus USA (“America”).

clue: Put Mr. Jackson in control of a trial, often (7)
explanation: PLACE (“put”) plus BO (“Mr. Jackson”) gives you PLACEBO (“control of a trial, often”).

clue: Peeled citrus fruit for a really nice person (5)
explanation: “Peel,” or remove the outer letters from, TANGELO to get ANGEL, a “really nice person.”

clue: Compare, at first, two articles by district attorney: “True North,” “Strong and Free” (6)
explanation: Happy ! CANADA, per its national anthem, is “true North, strong and free,” and is also C (“compare, at first,” or the first letter of COMPARE) plus the indefinite articles AN and A, plus DA (“district attorney”).

clue: “Hey, Ken—back off, tramp” (4)
explanation: This clue was not a dig at @ckstern! You get HIKE (“tramp”) from HI (“hey”) plus KEN with the “back off”—i.e., remove the last letter.

clue: Composer consumed by liver disease (5)
explanation: VERDI is the “composer” hidden in, or “consumed by,” the phrase “liVER DIsease.”

clue: Tsunami on broken peaks (9)
explanation: When the phrase TSUNAMI ON is “broken,” or anagrammed, you get MOUNTAINS (“peaks”).

clue: Oh, look, darling! Beginners just like me (3)
explanation: OLD (“just like me”) is made from the “beginners,” or first letters, of each of the first three words in the clue.

clue: Two guys come together in the city I’m visiting right now (7) 🇨🇦
explanation: At the time I wrote this clue, “the city I’m visiting right now” was CALGARY, which splits into two men’s names, CAL and GARY (“two guys come together”).

clue: Extreme hotel and places to stay outdoors announced (7)
explanation: INTENSE (“extreme”) is a homophone (“announced”) of INN TENTS (“hotel and places to stay”).

clue: Go fishing for percussion instrument? (8)
explanation: Happy Canada Day to those who celebrate! And happy  as well: CAST A NET (“go fishing”) gives you CASTANET, a “percussion instrument.” Question mark indicates the not-100%-literal wordplay.

clue: Nice, the French device (6)
explanation: KINDLE (“device”) is KIND (“nice”) plus LE (“the French,” or “the” in French).

clue: In confusion, ask peer for stereo component (7)
explanation: Anagram (“in confusion”) ASK PEER to get SPEAKER, a “stereo component.”

clue: Foodie is inside, testing our metalware (7)
explanation: GOURMET is the “foodie” found “inside” the phrase “testinG OUR METalware.”

clue: Part of the head’s sacred space (6)
explanation: In this double definition, the word TEMPLE is both “part of the head” and a “sacred space.” Yes, they have different etymologies!

clue: Bird eating bit of nut is ready to use right away (7)
explanation: Tough one! TURNKEY (“ready to use right away,” in a real-estate sense) is TURKEY (“bird”) “eating” the letter N. “Bit of” is a common indicator phrase meaning “take the first letter of the word that follows” (NUT, in this case).

clue: South Carolina superhero: The Hyena, say (9)
explanation: SCAVENGER (“the hyena, say”; ignore the deceptive capitalization) is SC (“South Carolina”) plus AVENGER (“superhero”).

clue: Beer, swallowed right, becomes bigger (6)
explanation: The typo was LARGER (“bigger”), which is LAGER (“beer,” the word that was meant on the sign in question) “swallowing” the letter R (“right”).

clue: Tell stories about storm (6)
explanation: REGALE (“tell stories”) is RE (“about,” as in the subject line of a memo sense) plus GALE (“storm”).

clue: Messy eaters’ holiday (6)
explanation: EASTER is the “holiday” you get from anagramming (“messy”) EATERS.

clue: Part of the leg is not feeling well, beset by pains (8)
explanation: ACHILLES is the “part of the leg” you get when ILL (“not feeling well”) is “beset by,” or put inside, the word ACHES (“pains”).

clue: Take both sides of dudes’ facial hair (6)
explanation: BEAR (“take,” in its “abide” sense) plus “both sides of”—that is, the first and last letters of—DUDES gives you BEARDS (“facial hair”).

clue: Lady takes possession of California road construction material (7)
explanation: MACADAM is the “road construction material” you get when MADAM (“lady”) “takes possession of” the letters CA (“California”).

clue: A rakish, unusual Colombian (7)
explanation: SHAKIRA is the “Colombian” you get from anagramming (“unusual”) A RAKISH.

clue: Boozy card game (5)
explanation: It’s time I explained a few things! RUMMY is both “boozy” and a “card game.” The etymology of the latter appears to be unknown but possibly from the liquor; I decided “unknown” was good enough to call it not an etymological dupe.

clue: Elephant omen masks spirit (7)
explanation: PHANTOM is the “spirit” that’s “masked” by, or hidden in, the phrase “elePHANT OMen.”

clue: Double praise, in retrospect (4)
explanation: Reverse (“in retrospect”) the word LAUD (“praise”) to get DUAL (“double”).

clue: Singer’s unhappy energy (4)
explanation: SADE is the “singer” you get from SAD (“unhappy”) plus E, an abbreviation for “energy.”

clue: Bar bill with rounds is verboten (5)
explanation: Add TAB (“bar bill”) to two letter Os (“rounds,” get it?) to get TABOO (“verboten”).

clue: #150 unit is secure (6)
explanation: CL is 150 in Roman numerals; add INCH, a “unit,” to get CLINCH, or “secure” (in the verb sense).

clue: Thrive like a staple? (8)
explanation: FLOUR is “a staple,” so “like a staple,” not literally (hence the question mark) is FLOUR-ISH, or FLOURISH (“thrive”).

clue: Actor Scott seizes railroad neighborhood (6)
explanation: It’s  again! BARRIO is the “neighborhood” you get when BAIO (“actor Scott”) “seizes” RR, the abbreviation for “railroad.”

clue: Generate small chess piece (5)
explanation: Easiest of the week: SPAWN, or “generate,” is S (“small”) plus PAWN (“chess piece”).

clue: Cartoon baby, denied opening, becomes collegian in Texas (5)
explanation: “Deny the opening”—that is, remove the first letter from—MAGGIE, a “cartoon baby,” to get AGGIE, a “collegian in Texas.”

clue: English philosopher is crooked, bad actor (7)
explanation: Jeremy BENTHAM is the “English philosopher” you get from BENT (“crooked”) plus HAM (“bad actor”).

clue: Mailed mayor constituents right now (8,3)
explanation: When this clue was posted, “right now” was MEMORIAL DAY, which can be made from the “constituents” (i.e., anagrammed) of MAILED MAYOR.

clue: Country of the Spanish invasion of body of water (6)
explanation: If you “invade” POND, a “body of water,” with LA (“the Spanish,” or “the” in Spanish), you get the “country” of POLAND.

clue: Officer’s phrase about the ladies? (7)
explanation: A SHE-RIFF is a “phrase about the ladies?” (The question mark indicates that the wordplay isn’t quite literal.) That gets you SHERIFF, an “officer.”

clue: NBA star with no time doubled up for band (5,5)
explanation: Take DURANT (“NBA star”), remove the T (“no time”), and “double up” the result to get a “band”—DURAN DURAN.

clue: Oil, say, that lady’s dad (6)
explanation: FAT (“oil, say”) plus HER (“that lady’s”) gives you FATHER (“dad”).

clue: Scare farm animal (3)
explanation: In this double definition, COW means both “scare” and “farm animal.”

clue: App in which successful runners make graffiti hit (9)
explanation: INS (“successful runners,” as in elected politicians”) plus TAG (“make graffiti”) plus RAM (“hit”) makes INSTAGRAM (“app”).

clue: Drag Race España star “Butt Sex Royalty” embraces part of California (3,7)
explanation: Couldn’t resist cluing ANA LOCKING (“Drag Race España star”) as ANAL KING (“butt sex royalty”) “embracing” OC (“part of California,” i.e., Orange County).

clue: Demoralize relative after drive (5)
explanation: Place AUNT, a “relative,” after the letter D (“drive” as in the car gear) to get DAUNT (“demoralize”).

clue: Not for polite company, like data transmission rates on the radio? (5)
explanation: BAWDY (“not for polite company”) is a homophone (“on the radio”) of BAUD-Y (“like data transmission rates”). Once again, the question mark indicates not-quite-literal wordplay.

clue: Between Utah and California, one city (5)
explanation: Put I (“one”) “between” UT and CA (the postal abbreviations for Utah and California) to get the “city” of UTICA.

clue: Give the wrong wig to S&M practitioner? (8)
explanation: A MISTRESS is the “S&M practitioner” you get from MIS-TRESS (“give the wrong wig to”). The question mark indicates that the wordplay is not fully literal.

clue: Flashy, filled with neutral decoration (7)
explanation: GARNISH (“decoration”) is GARISH (“flashy”) “filled with” the letter N (“neutral”).

clue: Announced lowland ski resort (4)
explanation: VAIL is the “ski resort” that’s a homophone (“announced”) of VALE (“lowland”).

clue: Possesses that guy’s hospital drug (7)
explanation: HASHISH (“drug”) is HAS (“possesses”) plus HIS (“that guy’s”) plus H (“hospital”).

clue: Elude a general explosion in addictive online pastime (13)
explanation: Anagram (“explosion”) ELUDE A GENERAL to get LEARNEDLEAGUE, an “addictive online pastime.” @LearnedLeague

clue: Wager nothing for Texas gubernatorial candidate (4)
explanation: BETO (“Texas gubernatorial candidate”) is BET (“wager”) plus O (“nothing,” as in zero).

clue: Rude dude’s body odor, or…? (4)
explanation: BOOR (“rude dude” is BO (“body odor”) plus OR (given in the clue).

clue: At the crack of ass, in the manner of a part of the head? (5)
explanation: EARLY (“at the crack of ass,” which is when I had to get up for my surgery last week) is EAR-LY, or “in the manner of a part of the head?” The question mark indicates non-literal wordplay.

clue: Actress rearranged petunia plot (5,6)
explanation: “Rearrange,” or anagram, PETUNIA PLOT to get PATTI LUPONE, an “actress.”

clue: Drunken pal loses the fifth (5)
explanation: Remove the fifth letter (“loses the fifth”) from FRIEND to get FRIED, or “drunken.”

clue: Florence West’s movement (4)
explanation: Add FLO (“Florence”) to W (“West”) to get FLOW (“movement”).

clue: Mythical creature to take forever (6)
explanation: DRAGON is a “mythical creature” you get from DRAG ON (“to take forever”).

clue: Newsworthy winner tricks heir deviously (4,6)
explanation: RICH STRIKE is the “newsworthy winner” (of the Kentucky Derby) that you get from anagramming (“deviously”) TRICKS HEIR.

clue: Plant sauce (4)
explanation: In this double definition, MOLE is a “plant” (as in a spy) and a “sauce” (in its two syllable form).

clue: Burn is Mother’s attractive quality (8)
explanation: Hi folks, I’m having surgery very early tomorrow morning, so  starts now. CHARISMA (“attractive quality”) is CHAR (“burn”) plus IS (given in the clue) plus MA (“Mother”).
